comments.commentBody:
We are conflating NOTHING! According to Wikipedia, "The U.S. finance industry comprised only 10% of total non-farm business profits in 1947, but it grew to 50% by 2010. Over the same period, finance industry income as a proportion of GDP rose from 2.5% to 7.5%, and the finance industry's proportion of all corporate income rose from 10% to 20%."

Our economic engine is breaking down due to too much "unproductive friction". We need an overhaul of the engine.

Scary looking grid, so few black squares, but it all fell pretty easily for me this Saturday. SW, then NW, filled in almost nonstop. Looked over at the east side, nearly blank (outside of ENO, naturally), but MER led to TRAINEDEYE, and before long, I was done. Only write-over: DER before DAS @39A. So call me Mr. Smartypants today.

CCS (a.k.a. Collective Consciousness Society) were a British studio ensemble that scored a few UK hits in the early 70s. Their instrumental version of Led Zeppelin's "Whole Lotta Love" was used as the theme song to the BBC music show "Top Of The Pops" for several years.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2SzQ7MGhgp8
How old is too old? How old is Hillary?
McCain lost because of his choice of running mate.  He'd have won if he'd chosen better.
Wow, Liz.  Just Wow.

The problem is that with this Administration, who has been proven to use Federal Agencies to go after their Political Foes, isn't going to use this SIGINT against American Citizens who disagree with the policies of this Administration and label people "Terrorists" just for purely Ideological reasons and hence use the NDAA to lock up their "Enemies" Indefinitely without our Guaranteed Constitutional Freedoms and Rights?
Sure they say they don't advertently go after American Citizens, but since when does the Federal Government tell the truth?

Agree, but mistakes are made. You wouldn't be saying that computers are infallible? And once you are targeted how do you rectify the error?
If your friend knows a friend who has an acquaintance who has a relative who is a crypto-terrorist, you are all on the watch list; after all, you might be a sleeper cell, and that means your family as well is watched and at what collateral damage? Is this unimaginable? Haven't our movies hinted that this is our future?

@s berger: agree. We are on a slippery slope. I think we're well into the SIGINT strategy with big computing (with better algorithms) and data, that is even bigger than the capabilities in the Poindexter days. It's too tempting to mine all the data and too difficult to control those who do.

I was just trying to remind the NSA that "it takes a village" and that in order to verify the statistical classifiers (associate them with real terrorists) it takes real spies. I was fortunate to have a brief conversation with William Colby a long time ago when I was in college. He recognized the SIGINT/HUMINT dichotomy. Then, SIGINT was satellites. I think the NSA is incorrectly driven totally to the SIGINT side, but we'll never know :-). Given the new DNI post, everyone is supposed to talk now, again a :-) to that.

Maybe the NSA could make a business out of this. I'm looking for a refrigerator, and it's actually difficult given the models and ratings. Were the NSA to know that, they'd have *real* data on all of the people who bought refrigerators, not just the Amazon, Sears, Lowe's or Home Depot reviews. One day I'd get an anonymous email from the NSA service, "We have found that the refrigerator that most people are really happy with is the Eisenkuehler 1500".

The service would be free. We pay taxes for it already.

One of the really big issues that readers might not understand is the internal dispute between SIGINT and HUMINT. Gaining human intelligence is valuable but very difficult (think of the John le Carre novels). SIGINT is a promise that removes the uncertain dependence on HUMINT by using assumed reliable computational algorithms.

HUMINT can point to individuals who are actual terrorists. At that point, using face recognition algorithms would be useful in tracking that particular person who is a verified suspect. If the NSA is thinking that only data-driven analysis (pure statistics, sans boots-on-the-ground intelligence) can save the day, they're naive, but also are lead into the very controversial intelligence activities that congress is now forced to restrict. But no one would forbid the NSA from tracking a real suspect (well, maybe the most extreme Libertarian).

Data-driven approaches involve collecting *all* the data and then looking for anomalies within that data. The NSA must have sold that to congress, notably back in the days of Adm. Poindexter's "Prism" project. Members of congress are not capable of understanding the nature of the HUMINT approach which is like a model of terrorism, and the SIGINT data-driven approach and its political consequences. SIGINT seems to promise a clean way of finding terrorists.

We have to find these terrorists and there is no substitute for learning about these people, just as we did in Soviet days.

"Like it or not, China is the only force can stabilize the Asian continent. "

Yes, absolutely. Totalitarian regimes do tend to stabilize.

(The Vietnamese government admitted that they had behind the Vietnamese protest.)

This claim is ludicrous

It is apparently still not at all close to those of the US and/or Japan's, otherwise, how would US so blatantly threaten to use its military force in the South China sea? We have not seen Obama threatening to use force in Creamea, right?

It is not real if one pays attention to the scale of the problems China is facing. Its backward political system, relationships with its neighbors, imbalanced economy, new threat from the terrorism, and the environmental challenges. Do you really believe that China is ready to dominate the world? Please don't make excuses for wanting a fight.

We can bully nations, but if we want them to follow us we must earn their respect. We are still respected and emulated in scientific research and pace of innovation. In these sectors we will dominate until we fund and grow our knowledge bases. Tomorrows general economic powerhouses will be the places where populations need products and services. With a quarter of India's or China's populations, we will dominate general consumer production and manufacturing sectors through our brands, who make significant investments in those markets.

Can someone explain to me why is that only China's claims on those disputed islands are "destabilising" but Vietnam's, Philippines'  and Japan's are not? Any territorial dispute has (at least) two sides. The only thing that distinguishes China from other claimants (apart from actual merits of their respective cases which are impossible to adjudicate objectively) is China's being a geopolitical rival of US and a dominant regional power. One would think that, far from being destabilising, a claim by a dominant power would instead end the dispute and make the situation more stable, as other parties would be reluctant to confront a militarily superior rival who they have no chance of defeating in a one-on-one conflict. That could be argued that it is the American support and alliances with US that encourage the weaker parties' intransigence and belligerence vis-a-vis China. One cannot but conclude that those insignificant disputes are being on purpose exploited by US to confront and contain China. That approach is as unwise as it is futile.
US was a free-market capitalist economy last time I checked. US government does not decide where private companies locate their manufacturing facilities. So much for that proposal.

Having sat at the imagined family gatherings for all of my black life, I can tell you: we don't spend our precious time talking all that much about, as the poet Langston Hughes put it, "the ways of white folks." For those families that do, here's a critical difference: the vast majority of them (dare I say all?) don't own the labor of white people the way Donald Sterling laid claim to. So what would be said in that context has to take that power differential into account.
Wow: racism's pay day is so grand, isn't it?
Nauseating.

Josh, is it simplistic to look simply at price paid at the beginning vs. the sale price? Shouldn't costs incurred along the way also factor in? (Salaries, advertising, etc.) Not saying the impact will be huge, but...
$2 Billion! What was I just reading in the NY Times about what would cost nearly $2 Billion? http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/28/us/detroit-task-force-says-blight-clea...
Ballmer didn't do anything for MS.  He is the definition of "right place right time".
Not a sports fan - would not blink an eye if NBA NFL MLB etc went away, but obvious to me that this is all a culmination of decades of malfeasance of this latest billionaire 'The Donald'
Funny enough, I don't think Sterling was ever recorded saying the N word.

Looking at the map of the islands.  China is not even close to some of them. This is an oil grab. They are out of their minds. At 52, I hope I live another 20 so I can see how this pans out. And by the way, to all Russian and Chinese citizens> What does it say when you see your governments supporting the most  crazy leaders in the world?

How do you take down a superpower? You befriend it. Take its technology and then attack. China’s military hackers Unit 61398 shutdown the pentagon 1500 defense dept. networks in 2007.

Now China’s usual attacks on banks, weapons manufacturers and other juicy targets are now back to almost daily. I don’t think this is going to end well. We have been one of their targets for some time now.

They have their eyes on controlling the Far-East and we have bases in Japan.

In my opinion, the advice President Obama is given is questionable at best.
It's a far more complex world now just in the last 50 years.
I believe that versions of terrorism are the largest threats in that country to country disputes are negotiable.
Terrorism requires 'at-home' solutions.
As for this country, we are sadly too mired in absurd political battles, to formulate a real strategy.
Define the Threat and prioritize the response.

The picky FT needs to be less "Financial" and more "Times" if it wants to deal with inequality, or we will start thinking that common sense has lost its balance on the other side of the Atlantic fulcrum...
